thread.title: Ethiopia: Ethiopian Airlines Flying High As Other Carriers Sink
thread.title_full: Ethiopia: Ethiopian Airlines Flying High As Other Carriers Sink

title: Ethiopia: Ethiopian Airlines Flying High As Other Carriers Sink
text:
Ethiopian Airlines Flying High As Other Carriers Sink Tagged: By Allan Olingo 
Ethiopian Airlines last week announced that it had exceeded its profits target for 2014. 
The airline posted a $175 million profit last year, exceeding its revenue targets, and dwarfing its main African competitors in Kenya and South Africa, who have posted losses and are sinking in debt. 
The state-owned carrier said that its passenger numbers grew from 5.2 million to more than six million passengers in 2014, aided by lower fares and strong inter-continental routes, especially to Kenya, South Africa and Nigeria. Related Topics Egypt: Mahlab, U.S Delegation Discuss Tourism Cooperation 
It now plans to double its fleet from the current 77 to 140 by 2025 as it positions itself to be Africa's largest carrier. 
While other major African airlines, including Kenya Airways and South African Airways, slid into loss, Ethiopian Airlines has grown its revenue and expanded its routes to become the most networked carrier on the continent. 
Last month, Kenya Airways posted a $251.1 million loss, attributing it to competition from Middle East carriers, hedging losses and high operating costs. 
The Kenyan airline has seen its losses grow by more than 600 per cent from the $28.9 million loss it posted in 2014, pushing its cumulative losses in the past three years to $442 million. 
South Africa Airways is also reeling under debt and losses but is afloat due to government-guaranteed loans. 
The airline has posted losses for the past two years and is currently in its ninth turnaround plan in 15 years. In 2014, it posted a loss of $124.4 million, from $108.8 million in 2013. 
According to the International Air Transport Industry Association, African airlines are expected to see the slowest growth among developing markets with a capacity and demand expansion of 3.3 per cent and 3.2 per cent respectively this year. Ethiopia
